title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 30, 2019).

Congressional antitrust investigators are scrutinizing plans by Google to use a new internet protocol, concerned that it could give the company a competitive advantage by making it harder for others to access consumer data.

The U.S. shale boom is slowing just as shale's importance in global markets has reached new highs following an attack on the heart of Saudi Arabia's oil infrastructure.

Boeing's expected fix for the 737 MAX will make its flight-control system more like an earlier version of the same system used on a military tanker jet.

Turmoil at WeWork is causing the shared-office-space firm to all but stop signing new leases, a fresh blow to New York's commercial-real-estate market.

Forever 21 filed for bankruptcy protection and plans to close dozens of stores amid a cash crunch.

Food52, a digital bazaar that sells upscale home goods, said it sold a majority stake to venture firm TCG for $83 million.

Concerns that planes could be targeted in cyberattacks are prompting U.S. officials to re-energize efforts to identify airliners' vulnerability.

Glaxo reported positive results in a clinical trial that the company's oncology-research chief said justified the decision to acquire cancer specialist Tesaro.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 30, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
